That's absolutely correct!

**Expose for the highlights:** Yes, it's generally better to expose for the highlights, as it's easier to recover shadow detail in post-processing than it is to recover blown-out highlights. By exposing for the highlights, you'll ensure that you capture the most detail in the brightest areas of the image.

**Adjust for clipping:** If you notice any clipping (peaks at the far left or right of the histogram), adjust your exposure settings to bring those peaks back within the graph. This will help prevent losing detail in those areas.

**Bracketing:** And if you're still unsure or want to play it safe, bracketing is a great way to cover your bases. By taking multiple shots at different exposure settings, you can merge them later using HDR software or choose the best exposure. This is especially useful in high-contrast scenes or when you're not sure what the ideal exposure is.

By following these steps, you'll be well on your way to capturing images with great dynamic range and detail.

Remember, practice makes perfect, so keep experimenting and reviewing your histogram to develop your skills. If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to ask!

Now, go out there and capture some amazing images!
